scenarioDescription:
The KELT-6 Exoplanetary System


Overview

KELT-6 is a star with 1.42 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.73 times its radius. It is located 785.14 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 6.1 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

KELT-6 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the KELT-6 system


KELT-6 b

KELT-6 b was discovered by the KELT observatory, in 2014-02, using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of KELT-6 b is 165.360 times the mass of Earth. The radius of KELT-6 b is 14.572 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, KELT-6 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


KELT-6 c

KELT-6 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory, in 2015-09, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 2.39 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of KELT-6 c is 1179.780 times the mass of Earth. The radius of KELT-6 c is 13.000 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, KELT-6 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system KELT-6, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the KELT.
name: KELT-6 - System With 2 Exolanets
